bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Charles L. Lhotka, January 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests documents dealing with U.S. Army activities in Cuba between 1899 and 1902.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Charles L. Lhotka, January 29, 1941
div1.opener:
January 29, 1941
Mr. Charles Lhotka
Department of Documents
Librarian, Public Library Chicago, Illinois
My dear Mr. Lhotka:
div1.p:
I have been asked by the Minister of National Defense of the Cuban
government to assist in the establishment of the true identities of the sites
used by the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board (Dr. Walter Reed and colleagues) in
1900, during the experiments which successfully identified the cause of yellow
fever. I would greatly appreciate your help in obtaining some data I have been
unable to obtain elsewhere. I found some important material in your library
when I visited it in November. The curator of the documents introduced me to
your secretary who asked you whether it would be possible for me to borrow some
of your U.S. army documents on inter-library loan through the Mayo Clinic.
You very kindly said that you thought this would be possible. These documents
are so numerous and so confusing to a layman that I hardly know myself which ones
I want, but I am most anxious to be permitted to study at leisure the various
reports of the U. S. army's activities in Cuba 1899 to 1902, especially the
reports of the Governor General of Cuba (that is the annual reports of 1899,
1900, 1901 and 1902). If I may be permitted to do so, may I first borrow
through the Mayo Clinic on inter-library loan, the following three volumes:
1. U. S. Adjutant General's office, Cuban division, department of
Cuba and department of Havana; annual report of the commanding general, 1899.
2. Same for 1900,
3. Same for 1901.

I cannot tell you how grateful I will be for your courtesy in
this matter, and if you could give me a list of the documents pertaining to the
annual reports of the governor general of Cuba for the years concerned, I would
appreciate it greatly. If it is easier for you to photostate such a list, I shall
be glad indeed to pay photostatic charges.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
